test_cases.issue_description: Customer is unable to change their plan immediately online and is forced to wait until the next billing cycle, despite needing more data urgently
test_cases.test_scenario: Test the online plan change functionality to ensure it allows customers to upgrade their plans immediately, with prorated charges, when they have used most of their data and have time left in their cycle
preconditions: Customer has used most of their data
Customer has time left in their billing cycle
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the customer portal
Step 2: Navigate to the plan management section
Step 3: Attempt to change the plan to a higher data plan
Step 4: Verify if the system allows the plan change with a prorated charge
Step 5: Verify if the system provides an option to purchase a data add-on as an alternative
test_cases.expected_result: The system should allow the customer to change their plan immediately, with a prorated charge, or provide an option to purchase a data add-on to get them through the cycle
test_cases.actual_issue: The system does not allow immediate plan changes online and forces customers to wait until the next billing cycle, leading to customer frustration and unnecessary support calls
edge_cases: Test with different plan types
Test with different data usage scenarios
Test with different billing cycle timelines
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer frustration, unnecessary support calls, and potential loss of business due to inability to meet customer needs in a timely manner

test_cases.issue_description: Port request gets stuck due to mismatch in name format between customer's account and web portal form
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that the web portal form for device activation and port request includes all required fields for customer's name, including middle initial, and that it matches the format required by the carrier (e.g. Verizon)
preconditions: Customer has a valid account with a carrier (e.g. Verizon) that includes a middle initial in their name
Customer has purchased a new phone from the website and is attempting to activate it and transfer their number
test_steps: Step 1: Fill out the device activation and port request form on the web portal with a name that includes a middle initial
Step 2: Verify that the form includes fields for first name, middle initial, and last name
Step 3: Submit the form and verify that the port request is successfully processed without getting stuck due to name format mismatch
Step 4: Repeat steps 1-3 with different name formats (e.g. with and without middle initial, with different punctuation) to ensure the form is robust
test_cases.expected_result: The port request is successfully processed and the customer's device is activated without delay, regardless of the name format used
test_cases.actual_issue: The port request gets stuck due to a mismatch in name format between the customer's account and the web portal form, causing service delays and customer dissatisfaction
edge_cases: Test with names that include multiple middle initials or suffixes (e.g. Jr, Sr)
Test with non-English characters in the name
test_cases.customer_impact: Service delays, customer dissatisfaction, and potential loss of business due to poor user experience

test_cases.issue_description: Customer is charged for international roaming without notification when their device connects to a foreign tower near the border
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that the system correctly notifies customers when their device is roaming internationally, even if they are physically within the country's borders
preconditions: Customer has an active account with international roaming enabled
Customer is near the border of the country with a foreign tower signal available
Customer's device is configured to automatically connect to the strongest available signal
test_steps: Step 1: Place the customer's device near the border of the country, within range of a foreign tower signal
Step 2: Verify that the device connects to the foreign tower signal
Step 3: Simulate data usage or make a call to trigger roaming charges
Step 4: Verify that the customer receives a notification or warning about international roaming charges
Step 5: Check the customer's account to ensure that the roaming charges are accurately reflected
test_cases.expected_result: The customer receives a notification or warning about international roaming charges when their device connects to a foreign tower signal, and the charges are accurately reflected on their account
test_cases.actual_issue: Customers are not receiving notifications or warnings about international roaming charges when their device connects to a foreign tower signal near the border, resulting in unexpected charges
edge_cases: Test with different device types and models
Test with varying network signal strengths and configurations
Test at different locations near the border
test_cases.customer_impact: Unexpected international roaming charges can cause significant financial harm and damage to the customer's trust in the service provider

test_cases.issue_description: Pricing discrepancy between product page and checkout page for device purchase
test_cases.test_scenario: Verify that pricing information is consistent and clearly indicates any conditions (e.g. new line activation) on the product page and checkout page
preconditions: User is logged in to their account on the web portal
User has an existing line to upgrade
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the device purchase page for a specific phone model (e.g. Samsung Galaxy A54)
Step 2: Verify the price displayed on the product page
Step 3: Attempt to purchase the device as an upgrade to an existing line
Step 4: Verify the price displayed on the checkout page
Step 5: Check for any conditional pricing information (e.g. 'price with new line activation') on both the product page and checkout page
test_cases.expected_result: The price displayed on the product page and checkout page should be the same, and any conditional pricing information should be clearly indicated on both pages
test_cases.actual_issue: Pricing discrepancy between product page and checkout page, with conditional pricing information not clearly indicated
edge_cases: Test with different device models and price points
Test with different types of plans (e.g. prepaid, postpaid) and promotions
Test with different user account scenarios (e.g. new customer, existing customer with multiple lines)
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer time wasted, trust, and potential financial impact due to unexpected pricing

test_cases.issue_description: Plan change buttons are non-responsive for customers with multiple add-ons
test_cases.test_scenario: Test plan change functionality for customers with multiple add-ons
preconditions: Customer has an account with multiple add-ons (e.g. international calling and mobile hotspot)
Customer is using a supported browser (e.g. Chrome)
test_steps: Step 1: Login to the customer portal with a test account that has multiple add-ons
Step 2: Navigate to the plan change page
Step 3: Click on the plan options to attempt to change the plan
Step 4: Verify that the plan change buttons respond and allow the customer to change their plan
test_cases.expected_result: The plan change buttons should respond and allow the customer to change their plan without any issues
test_cases.actual_issue: The plan change buttons are non-responsive and do not allow the customer to change their plan
edge_cases: Test with different combinations of add-ons
Test with different browsers and devices
test_cases.customer_impact: Silent failures, customers are unable to change their plans online, leading to frustration and potential churn

test_cases.issue_description: Existing customers are unable to apply promotional codes intended for new customers, despite receiving emails with valid codes
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that promotional codes are correctly validated based on customer type (new or existing) and that email communications clearly indicate any restrictions
preconditions: Existing customer account with associated email address
Promotional code created with restriction to new customers only
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the web portal as an existing customer
Step 2: Attempt to apply a promotional code restricted to new customers only
Step 3: Verify that the system correctly identifies the customer as existing and prevents application of the code
Step 4: Check the email communication associated with the promotional code to ensure it clearly indicates the restriction to new customers only
test_cases.expected_result: The system should prevent existing customers from applying promotional codes intended for new customers only and email communications should clearly indicate any restrictions
test_cases.actual_issue: Existing customers are able to attempt to apply promotional codes intended for new customers, resulting in 'code not valid' errors and customer frustration
edge_cases: Test with different types of promotional codes (e.g. percentage off, dollar amount off)
Test with different customer account statuses (e.g. active, inactive, suspended)
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer frustration and potential loss of trust in the company due to unclear or misleading promotional communications

test_cases.issue_description: Mobile app crashes when selecting a new device for upgrade on Android devices with more than 100 apps installed
test_cases.test_scenario: Test device upgrade feature on Android devices with varying number of installed apps
preconditions: Android device with Total Wireless mobile app installed
More than 100 apps installed on the device
Device upgrade option available in the app
test_steps: Step 1: Launch the Total Wireless mobile app on an Android device
Step 2: Navigate to the device upgrade section
Step 3: Select a new device for upgrade
Step 4: Verify if the app crashes or throws an error
Step 5: Repeat steps 2-4 with different numbers of installed apps (e.g., 50, 100, 150) to identify the threshold for the crash
test_cases.expected_result: The mobile app should allow device upgrade selection without crashing, regardless of the number of installed apps
test_cases.actual_issue: The mobile app crashes when selecting a new device for upgrade on Android devices with more than 100 apps installed, due to memory management issues
edge_cases: Test with different Android versions
Test with different device manufacturers
Test with different numbers of background apps running
test_cases.customer_impact: Core functionality unavailable on mobile, forcing customers to use alternative channels, resulting in a poor customer experience

test_cases.issue_description: Customer unable to disable auto-pay in mobile app when enrolled through website
test_cases.test_scenario: Test disabling auto-pay in mobile app for accounts enrolled in auto-pay through website
preconditions: Customer has an account with auto-pay enabled through the website
Customer has the latest version of the mobile app installed
test_steps: Step 1: Enable auto-pay for a test account through the website
Step 2: Log in to the mobile app with the test account credentials
Step 3: Navigate to 'Account Settings' and then 'Payment Settings'
Step 4: Verify the presence of an option to disable auto-pay
test_cases.expected_result: The option to disable auto-pay is present and functional in the mobile app
test_cases.actual_issue: The option to disable auto-pay is missing in the mobile app for accounts enrolled through the website
environmental_dependencies: Mobile device with latest OS version
Latest version of the mobile app
edge_cases: Test with different payment methods
Test with multiple accounts and auto-pay enrollment methods
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer is unable to manage their account features through their preferred channel, leading to frustration and potential churn
